Whatever possibilities there are for accommodation between them, they ought to be the subject of negotiations between the two parties, but not here. I suggest if the House passes the Deputy's amendment that that is the course that ought to be adopted in fairness to the county council, to the present corporation in the city, and in fairness to Rathmines, Pembroke, Dalkey and the other places.

Supposing for the sake of argument that the amendment before the House is put and defeated and the Government win, is the President then prepared to go into the question of Section 3 as to whether the borough should be set up or not?
That is another matter. I am not wedded to the same extent to that.

That is the real position. That is what Deputy Thrift's suggestion hinges on. The Minister has already stated that he has not turned down Deputy Thrift's suggestion, but the President has turned it down.

No. If I were a member of the Dublin Corporation I would be prepared to stand for the amalgamation of Rathmines and Pembroke, but I would not recommend and I would vote against the proposal to take in Blackrock, Dun Laoghaire, Dalkey and Killiney.
Does the President insist on the coastal borough?

I insist on the coastal borough to this extent, that it appears to me to be a better proposition from the point of view of the further ultimate extension of the city and for the intermediate government of these places to have the coastal borough. But I am not committed to it to the same extent as I am committed to not extending the boundary of the city beyond the limits of Section 2.

If I understand the President aright, his position is the same as that of Deputy Thrift's— that for the moment he is wedded to the suggestion in the Bill that the boundaries be only extended to take in Rathmines and Pembroke on the southern side, but that he is not wedded for the moment entirely to the setting up of a borough.
What we call betrothed.

Yes, betrothed and not wedded. That is Deputy Thrift's position. If the President would agree with the proposition that the immediate setting up of the borough would be dropped we would be prepared to withdraw Deputy MacEntee's amendment.

We are as anxious about this matter as Deputy Good who, if I may say so with all respect, made one of the most effective speeches which I have heard for a long time in this House on this section. We are not out to gain any Party advantage out of this Bill. We are anxious, as, I think is every Deputy who either lives here or who is interested in the city, to promote the welfare of Dublin. I know that the President has its interests at heart too and, knowing that, I am rather astonished that he takes the view on this matter that he does. In the past I think he always stood for a big Dublin, a Dublin of which we could be proud. As it is. Dublin is no mean city but it could have been much bigger and greater in the past were it not for political affairs over which we had no control. We have, however, control now and can make Dublin what it ought to be, a great city of a great nation. To my mind we are putting one obstacle in the way of making that city what it ought to be by setting up this borough. The President is a man who—without disrespect to anybody else—is probably the guide in this matter so far as the Local Government Department is concerned, and in my opinion if he reconsiders the matter and takes the view of a Dublin citizen, having the real interest and welfare of the city at heart, he will waive the suggestion that this borough should be set up now by the passing of the next section.

MainHeading.P: If this amendment is defeated there will probably be no chance of bringing it on again, and the next section will come along, setting up that borough, and thus we will be putting an obstacle, which does not exist at present, in our way. We do not want it, and if it does not suit the city council after examination to take in the additional areas of Dun Laoghaire, Blackrock and other districts this year or next year we do not want to force them. We do not want the borough set up because we believe that it would be an obstacle in the way, as there would be vested interests created which would fight hard to prevent absorption in the future. I believe that the President is anxious to see the city a worthy capital of the country, and I appeal to him not to set up this obstacle but to leave the matter open. Even though there might be some slight temporary advantage gained by the citizens under that head I think we should put it aside and give the new city council an opportunity of taking those areas in, one by one or two by two, if in their wisdom if, having taken counsel with the new bodies that will be added to them, they think it wise to do so. I think I have a large section of the House with me in urging the President to take that course.

Speaker.P: We must clear out of our way the amendment to put the four urban districts into the city. Then, in regard to Section 3, I would make this case in favour of unifying the four urban districts. Blackrock rates for the coming year are higher than those in the city. Blackrock and Dun Laoghaire have a joint drainage system which, in spite of what is generally said, is satisfactory. It is discharged outside near the pier on the outgoing tide.
Only during the last few months.

That is the way it is going. Dalkey drains on the foreshore and that drainage could be linked up to Dun Laoghaire and Blackrock. You want that done under a joint body. I am not satisfied with the way in which Dalkey urban affairs are being administered. I do not want to go into the manner in which those affairs are being dealt with at present, but the position is most unsatisfactory. If we are going to hang on for a certain number of years, leaving Blackrock in the position that for one reason or another its rates are higher than those of the city, leaving Dalkey in the position in which, owing to want of joint control, it cannot link up its drainage with the other districts and in which you have complaints about the fore-shore, and also if Dalkey is perhaps to be run by a Commissioner, you will have a situation in the four urban districts which I do not think could be very well justified. I would argue on Section 3 that that general state of affairs needs to be pulled together. You need a unified mind working over the area and you need the manager system operating there to bring about improvements. That is the case I would make on Section 3 to bring about the amalgamation of these areas, but let us deal with Deputy MacEntee's amendment once and for all and them let us discuss anything we like on Section 3.

I would suggest to the Minister not to move Section 3 at this stage to enable, between this and the Report Stage, the position to be discussed by the conference suggested by Deputy Thrift in order to see whether an agreed section could not be introduced.
An agreed section as to what?
As to the coastal borough, in order to see whether it is to be left as it is or what arrangement could be come to.
Does the Deputy agree that if the valuation of the county is to be reduced by £500,000 that that is a case that calls for——
I think the President misunderstands me.
The Deputy is not on that point at all?

No. The proposal is to set up a coastal borough. The county council position will not be affected whether the borough is set up or not. In either case, I take it that the Department of Local Government is satisfied that a workable arrangement is possible. The question is, if the amendment of Deputy MacEntee is not put, whether the Minister will agree not to move Section 3, which commits the House to the establishment of the coastal borough. Do I take it that that is agreed to?
It is suggested that, having defeated Deputy MacEntee's amendment——
Is that the suggestion? That if Deputy MacEntee's amendment is defeated, Section 3, subject to agreement, will not be moved at the present stage?
If no agreement is reached in the interval, the Minister could introduce it on the next Stage.
What would Deputy Lemass do with the amendment then?
Withdraw it.
And it will never subsequently be heard of?
I beg your pardon, it will.
If the conference decides that no agreement is possible we can return to the status quo.
Oh, no.

The real difficulty we are in is that if at this particular Committee Stage Deputy MacEntee's amendment were withdrawn, it could be brought in again on next Stage, and we would then begin, as we began this evening, and have it all over again, unless there is agreement in the interval. If the amendment were withdrawn and Section 3 were discussed and if it stood in its present form, you could not propose an amendment at this Stage putting the coastal borough into the city, because if we decided to leave Section 3 as it is, we would have decided that there would be a separate coastal borough. If there is withdrawal of the amendment it might be proposed again.

My suggestion is as follows: that we dispose of Deputy MacEntee's amendment, and subject to the ruling of the Ceann Comhairle on the matter of order, I am prepared not to commit the House to the principle of amalgamating the four urban districts under Section 3. I am further prepared to go on with such consideration of the Bill as is not involved in a decision one way or another on that point, and either at some other part of the Committee Stage—or again, subject to the ruling of the Ceann Comhairle—on the Report Stage decide the principle of Section 3 one way or another in accordance with whatever agreement may be arrived at at any conference.

My attitude in the matter is that I am willing to meet the Minister half way, but I am not prepared to allow him to walk over me as he suggests. If the Minister does not move Section 3 now, on the understanding that the conference which Deputy Thrift suggests should take place, I am prepared to withdraw the amendment——
No.
——and to consider our future position in the light of what transpires at the conference. My point of view is practically the same as that of Deputy Thrift and Deputy Good.
I will mark a difference in a minute.

I think the Minister is taking an unfair advantage now. There has been a very reasonable suggestion which we have met in a reasonable way. We think that the status quo should be maintained and that we should have the right to withdraw the amendment now and to introduce it again for further discussion. Supposing Deputy Thrift, in the course of the discussion at the conference, was converted to my point of view, is he going to be prevented from supporting it by his vote in the House?
He would be a pervert then.

That may be, but the President has not succeeded in converting Deputy Thrift or Deputy Good to his point of view yet. It is because he despairs of that that he is anxious to have this amendment disposed of in such a way that it would not come before the House again.

I think I explained to the Deputy that as long as the Deputy's amendment remains, the Bill is in danger of destruction. His amendment will have to be defeated. I propose to defeat it to-night and if it is so defeated, not to take a decision on Section 3 but to leave it over for further consideration.
I take it that the position is that Deputy MacEntee's amendment will be put and voted on and that if it is defeated, Section 3 will not be moved?
Yes.

I am anxious to point out that I do not think that Deputy MacEntee realises the necessity for coming to a decision on that point as to whether the districts covered by the coastal borough are to be brought into the city now or not. It would be satisfactory if he withdrew his amendment and it would be clearly understood that that was a decision that these areas were not to be brought at the present moment into the city. If that can only be arrived at by a division that division must be taken now. I thought Deputy MacEntee's attitude was to let that decision betaken and then take up the position as to what is to be done with these areas.
The position is that Deputy MacEntee's amendment must be withdrawn or defeated.
We would not agree to its withdrawal.
Therefore the proposal only stands in the event of Deputy MacEntee's amendment being defeated. Surely the President does not expect us to vote for its defeat?

There is one other point. If this amendment is disposed of and the Minister, as he states, is going to be in a position to argue on the lines that the Blackrock rates are so high, that the administration of Dalkey is unsatisfactory, and you have decided you are not going to bring these districts into the city now, what is left? Are you going to allow Blackrock, with its uneconomic administration, Dalkey with its unsatisfactory administration and Dun Laoghaire, to continue to exist as separate entities?
Possibly. It depends on counter-balancing advantages.
The cards are on the table.

They are. In view of the dilemma into which the House is going to be put by the Minister once my amendment is out of the way, the House ought to be able to retain liberty of action in the matter and be able to come to Section 3 with an entirely unprejudiced mind. The House should compel the Minister to permit the amendment to be withdrawn.
According to the Deputy if certain Deputies, knowing what the Minister has said, vote for putting those districts into the city they will be taking a terrible responsibility.

We must either put this amendment from the Chair and have a decision on it or Deputy MacEntee must agree that the area of the city will not be made any greater than it is by Section 2 by any further amendment. The withdrawal of the amendment, however, would have the same effect if the Deputy were to say that he would not again propose the amendment so as to put these four coastal boroughs into Section 2.

So as to put the whole area at present under the control of the four urban councils into the city. I submit that it is not right that the President should preclude the House from including Blackrock if it so desired.
The President could not do it.
That is what he intended.
The Deputy overestimates my power.
That is a different question altogether. It is a question of order.
We would be still entitled to introduce an amendment suggesting that Blackrock might be included.
It is your last chance.

If the amendment is withdrawn the Deputy is in the position he was in before he moved it. If the amendment is withdrawn I would not be prepared to give a decision now, but he might be able to move the other amendment, that is, for the smaller area of Blackrock.
I will take that.
Do not give him too much information.
What is the Deputy doing then? I am not now ruling.
We will take a vote on it.
Amendment 7 put.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S.T. O'Kelly Mr. S.T. O'Kelly
Speaker.P: I move amendment 17:
In sub-section (1), line 14, to delete the words “thirty-five” and substitute the words “forty-five.”

After a discussion with a number of my colleagues who were interested in this, they succeeded in getting me to reduce the figure to forty-five. I wanted the number to be sixty. After a great deal of discussion, they insisted that forty-five would be an adequate number to get representation for all classes that should be represented on the council —a council which will include so many diversified interests. I realise, having had some little experience of the old municipal council of Dublin, which had a membership of eighty, that that number was too large if you like. My own personal belief is that a council consisting of sixty members would certainly be required to give adequate representation to all the interests involved. When you take in the added areas of Pembroke and Rathmines the council will be representing a population of almost 400,000 people. With a population of that size, and taking into account the diversity of interests that are to be found amongst the people in a capital city like Dublin and the various types of mind that will be clamouring for expression, I think it is a moderate request to ask that 45 members should form the council.

MainHeading.P: If you take, say, two or three big organisations, organisations that deal with purely civic problems and in which politics only enter in a minor way, you will have in these a clash of interests and points of view demanding expression that a number such as 35 will not provide adequate representation for on the council. A city with a population of 400,000 people may be said to be a large city. Under the new arrangement proposed in this Bill, if it goes through, the administration of the city will be in the hands largely of officials. The matter of appointment to the various offices, great or small, will be matters of administration and will be outside the purview of the council. Questions of legislation will be within the power of the new council, and when questions of legislation are being discussed the wider the number of points of view that can find expression inside the council the better the result will be, within certain limits.

The limit suggested in the amended form by the Minister would not, I am quite satisfied, be sufficient. Personally, I would rather have 60, so that minor interests might be able to elect a representative to the council, as such a representative might prove a most valuable member. It is extraordinary sometimes where one gets wisdom from—“out of the mouth of babes” as the old proverb says—and in my experience of public bodies very small and insignificant interests produced men who were of the utmost value in the corporation. Having in view that experience, I urge upon the House the necessity for enlarging the council to the suggested number—45. I think the city would benefit by that, and I am of opinion that we will not get adequate representation for the classes who are entitled to representation in a body in which such important interests are at stake as in the council of the capital of Ireland if we restrict the number to 35.

Speaker.P: I am in complete agreement with every word that Deputy O'Kelly has said. I would be glad if the Minister would see his way to accept the number suggested—45. If the Minister is of opinion that he cannot go the whole way to meet Deputy O'Kelly's amendment, I think the least he might do is to strike a happy medium and accept the number I have suggested and place the size of the council at 40. The old corporation, as Deputy O'Kelly pointed out, numbered 80, and the new council, if the Minister accepts my amendment, will be only half the size of the original body. The Minister ought to bear in mind the argument Deputy O'Kelly has put before the House, that in a city numbering almost 400,000 inhabitants, with great diversity of interests, every possible care should be taken, as far as humanly possible, to give the various kinds of interests representation on the council. I completely agree with Deputy O'Kelly when he says that if only 35 are elected on the council that diversity of interest will not be represented. Moreover, one has to remember that if such a small council as 35 is set up, and if that council is to function with any effect in the carrying out of municipal affairs, there would have to be a very regular attendance of those 35 members if the business of the city is to be properly conducted. In this House we have paid representatives, and Whips of the Parties know the difficulties they are faced with in keeping the different units of their Parties in attendance in the House. What will that difficulty be in the Council of Dublin, where there is no such stimulus as the Whips to have members present to carry out the business? In my opinion the minimum number that could possibly carry on the business of the council would be 40. I do not know if the Minister would go the whole way to meet Deputy O'Kelly. If he would I would be more grateful to him than if he accepted the number 40.

MainHeading.P: No doubt the small committees functioning in the new council will make for greater expedition and despatch in municipal affairs, but for adequate discussion of municipal affairs 35 is an insufficient membership, considering the number of problems they will have to deal with —problems of policy and finance and many other matters that will from time to time arise. If we send only a small number of representatives to the new council we will be burking reasonable discussion, and we will not be discussing the affairs of the city in the way they are entitled to be discussed. I would also ask the Minister to bear in mind that two areas which are being taken in, Rathmines and Pembroke, have succeeded in getting a particularly good type of councillors to represent them. If you enlarge the number of the new council you will be encouraging that particularly good type of councillors to come in, and you will be giving scope for the activities and experience of those members, which I have not the slightest doubt will not alone be in the interests of Dublin proper, but also in the interests of Rathmines and Pembroke when they come in under the Bill. I have no wish to have unnecessary discussion of ordinary municipal affairs, but I suggest to the Minister that with a population of almost 400,000 in the city to send in only 35 members to the council will not serve the interests of the city in the same way as if he accepted Deputy O'Kelly's amendment or the amendment in my name.

Speaker.P: I would like to hear some comment from the Deputy on his amendment No. 23.
There is a misprint in that amendment, and I do not intend to move it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. O'Connell Mr. T.J. O'Connell
Speaker.P: I ask the Minister to adhere to the number 35. That figure was put down after considerable thought over the matter. We felt that there are arguments in favour of a small council, but that the Minister had gone too much in that direction when he fixed the number at 25. I think 35, which is now the number in the Bill, is reasonable.

I have advanced from 25 to 35. I think that 35 is a reasonable number to conduct the business of the council properly. I think if Deputies look around and imagine 35 seats filled they will realise that it is a sufficient number to act on the council. In the new circumstances, in respect of such committees as the council desires to set up for technical education or libraries they are given power to appoint persons not necessarily members of the council, but persons interested in the matters for which the committees are especially required, that is persons with special experience, interests and training, the type of persons who would not go in for ordinary municipal affairs, and who would not face the electorate and incur the expense that necessarily arises in connection with that.

I am not impressed by the argument that there are various types of minds clamouring for expression and that they ought to find their way into the council. Some of these people might be doing fretwork or painting pictures for the Royal Hibernian Academy or something like that. What we want are elected representatives of the people who will go into the council for the purpose of discussing the business matters that arise there. A council of thirty-five should be sufficiently representative of the city to have the city's voice clearly heard. If there are minor notes, they will be heard as part of public opinion and, heard as part of public opinion, they will react on members of the council. People who are not represented in the council are not deprived of the power of arguing out their point merely by that fact. Public opinion exercises a considerable amount of weight with the members of a council carrying on the business of a city. The members of a council cannot, in fact, carry on the business of the council satisfactorily or properly except they are in touch with general public opinion. I suggest that a council of thirty-five is ample for our purpose.

The proposal of the Minister that the council should be one of thirty-five members is more reasonable than the proposal contained in the Bill originally but I submit it is less reasonable than the proposal that the council should consist of forty-five members. The Minister asked us to imagine thirty-five persons sitting in the benches here in this chamber. I think it has been the experience of all of us that discussions here on any questions of importance are always much better when the actual attendance of Deputies is larger than it is, say, at the present moment. There is an argument in favour of setting up a council of forty-five that has nothing whatever to do with the number of voters each member would represent. I refer to the atmosphere that would be created in the council chamber when matters relating to municipal policy would be under discussion. The theory that a small council is best applies only to executive committees, of which this council will not be one. This council will be a legislative body. It will be discussing matters of policy only and it should be sufficiently large to give a proper air of importance to its deliberations, as well as to ensure that all interests of sufficient importance will be represented. A council of thirty-five implies only thirty elected members. I am rather surprised that the Labour Party should favour the smaller council in this case because the section of the community most likely to be deprived of representation in consequence of the reduction in the number of the council will be the section for whom the Labour Party claims to speak. I think it worked out in that way in the city of Cork. The candidates there who claimed to represent the business interests got a very much larger proportion of the seats than the candidates who stood in the labour interests.

MainHeading.P: A council of forty-five in the proposed new City of Dublin means one member of the Muncipal Council to every 9,000 of the population—I merely quote round figures. I do not think that that basis of representation is unreasonable. The original proposal of the Minister contained in the Bill made the representation on the Municipal Council correspond with the representation of the city in the Dáil. That is improved upon, I admit, by accepting the proposal to make the council thirty-five, but still I think that the fact that there should be a much wider basis of representation in local government than in national government would justify a further extension of the size of the council to forty-five. There are interests in the city concerned in the results of municipal administration which should be represented on the Municipal Council, but which may not be represented if there are only thirty elected members. There are limits, no doubt, to the size of the council. I do not think personally that forty-five is too small. I think it represents just the right balance between the necessity for getting a proper representation of all views and the undesirability of having a loquacious body discussing matters of policy. The loquacity of a body increases in proportion to its numbers.

There are other considerations which must be taken into account. I think it has been the experience of most people that intrigue and corruption are much more likely to develop in small councils than in large councils. The importance of the individual increases as the size of the council diminishes, and individuals are likely to be influenced by personal consideration. On the larger councils, it is groups and parties that exercise control, and groups and parties are less likely to be influenced by corrupt methods than are individuals. That point should be taken into account. Personally, I do not see that there will be much room for corruption in the new Municipal Council, with the limited powers which the Minister proposes to give it. At the same time, it is desirable that group policies should operate rather than individual views. There are certain principles which should determine the size of any legislative body, whether that body be a national body, like this Dáil, or a municipal body or county council. It is not correct, as the Minister appears to think, that the size of a council should vary in direct proportion to the volume of its revenue. Other considerations must be taken into account. I do not think any Deputy would hold that if this Dáil consisted of thirty-five members its business would be done in any better manner than it is done at present. Possibly it is too large at present, but at the same time, if we were to reduce its membership to thirty-five, we would merely have a committee. We would have much more scrappy discussions than at present on important matters of policy. Possibly, details of administration might be attended to in a better way, but important matters of policy and the ideas and ideals that influence administration would be considered in a much more scrappy way, if they were considered at all.

The Government's original proposal of twenty-five members was obviously only a bargaining proposal. They have proved themselves to be bad bargainers by advancing too soon. I wonder if we could get them to advance further? The number suggested by Deputy O'Kelly is not a bargaining proposal. It was the figure arrived at after definite consideration by this Party. Views were expressed in favour of a smaller number and views were expressed in favour of a larger number. Finally, we arrived at the conclusion that forty-five would be a reasonable number for the council, that it would secure proper representation for all interests and, at the same time, preserve an atmosphere which would ensure that matters of policy would be properly discussed when the council was in session.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P.S. Doyle Mr. P.S. Doyle
Speaker.P: I rise to support the amendment providing for thirty-five members which appears in the names of Deputy O'Connell and myself. Past experience of a council of eighty suggested to me that thirty-five would be about the proper number for this council. Under the council of eighty, a considerable amount of business was carried on by various committees. I take it that, under the scheme of city managership, a lot of this administrative work, which was formerly performed by committees, will be discharged by the City Manager. As a result, it will not be necessary to have a very large council. I think, with Deputy O'Connell, that thirty-five members is quite a reasonable number.
